60 seconds.definition: A period of time equal to one minute (sixty seconds). Em português: um período de tempo equivalente a um minuto (sessenta segundos).
examples: The test will last 60 seconds, so you need to answer quickly.
She only had 60 seconds to finish the sentence before the timer ran out.

a few more.definition: a few more: a small additional number of something; a few more minutes, a few more people. (mais alguns: um pequeno número adicional de algo; mais alguns minutos, mais algumas pessoas)
examples: We need a few more minutes to finish the project.
She invited a few more guests to the party.

acting.definition: The art or skill of performing in a play, film, or other performance; a arte ou habilidade de representar em uma peça, filme ou outra performance.
examples: Her acting in the film was praised by critics.
He studied acting at the drama school.

actions.definition: An action is a thing that is done or performed; uma ação é algo que é feito ou executado.
examples: The committee decided to take immediate actions to address the issue.
Her actions during the crisis saved many lives.

adjectives.definition: Adjectives are words that describe or modify nouns, providing more information about their characteristics, quantity, or state.
examples: The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
She wore a bright red dress.

advanced.definition: Having a higher level of skill, knowledge, or experience; more complex or sophisticated.
examples: She has an advanced understanding of calculus.
The advanced course will cover quantum mechanics.

alphabet.definition: The set of letters or symbols used in a particular language to represent its sounds.
examples: The alphabet is the foundation of reading and writing.
She learned the alphabet before she started learning to read.

although.definition: used to introduce a fact that makes the main statement seem surprising or unlikely
examples: Although it was raining, we went for a walk.
She passed the exam, although she had not studied much.

anything.definition: Any object, person, or thing; used to refer to something unspecified.
examples: I don't have anything to wear.
Do you need anything else?

anywhere.definition: at or to any place; at any location
examples: I can go anywhere you want.
He didn't know where to go, so he went anywhere.

apostrophe.definition: A punctuation mark (') used to indicate possession or the omission of letters in contractions.
examples: It's a beautiful day.
Don't forget to bring your books.

as as.definition: Used to compare or indicate similarity.
examples: She sings as as well as he does.
He worked as as diligently as his colleague.

basics.definition: The fundamental principles or essential elements of something, often referring to the simplest or most basic aspects.
examples: She taught us the basics of cooking, starting with how to boil water and chop onions.
Learning the basics of a new language is essential before moving on to more advanced grammar.

beach.definition: A stretch of land along the shore of a sea, ocean, or lake, often sandy and used for recreation.
examples: We spent the whole afternoon sunbathing on the beach.
The waves crashed against the rocks as we walked along the beach.

beauty.definition: The quality or combination of qualities that pleases the senses or mind; attractiveness or aesthetic appeal.
examples: She admired the beauty of the sunset over the ocean.
The artist captured the beauty of the city in his painting.
expressions: beauty is in the eye of the beholder

become.definition: To begin to be or to have a particular quality or state; to transform into a different condition or form.
examples: She became a teacher after completing her degree.
The situation became more complicated as time passed.

belongs to.definition: Indicates possession or association, meaning that something is owned by or associated with a particular person, group, or category.
examples: This book belongs to me.
The responsibility belongs to the manager.

boring.definition: Uninteresting or dull; lacking excitement or variety.
examples: The lecture was so boring that many students fell asleep.
He found the movie boring and left the theater early.

borrow.definition: To take and use something belonging to someone else with the intention of returning it later.
examples: Can I borrow your umbrella?
She borrowed a book from the library.

business.definition: An organization or activity that involves making and selling goods or services, or the conduct of such activities.
examples: She started a small business selling handmade crafts.
The business was struggling during the recession.

chatted.definition: Engaged in informal conversation, typically in a relaxed or friendly manner.
examples: After the meeting, they chatted about their weekend plans.
She chatted with her friends on the phone for hours.

cheerful.definition: Feeling or showing happiness and optimism; bright and lively
examples: She greeted everyone with a cheerful smile.
The cheerful music lifted the mood of the entire room.

chilling.definition: (verb) To relax or unwind; (adjective) Cool or pleasantly cold; (noun) A state of relaxation or coolness.
examples: After a long day at work, I just want to be chilling on the couch.
The temperature in the room is chilling, so I turned on the heater.

choose.definition: To select or pick something from a range of options.
examples: You should choose a healthy breakfast before heading to work.
When given the chance, she chose to study abroad.

classroom.definition: A room in a school where lessons are taught and students learn.
examples: The teacher arranged the desks in a circle in the classroom to encourage discussion.
During the lockdown, students had to adapt to online classes from their home classrooms.

clickbait.definition: A headline, title, or link designed to attract attention and encourage people to click on it, often by using sensational or misleading content.
examples: You won't believe what happened next!
This one trick will change your life forever!

closing.definition: The act of bringing something to an end or concluding it; the final part of an event, meeting, or transaction.
examples: The closing of the conference was marked by a keynote speech.
She was nervous about the closing of the deal, hoping the terms would be favorable.

clothes.definition: Garments worn by a person, typically covering the body.
examples: She bought new clothes at the mall.
The clothes were too expensive for his budget.

clumsy.definition: Lacking coordination or skill; awkward in movement or action.
examples: He was clumsy when he tried to lift the heavy box, spilling his coffee in the process.
Her clumsy attempt at dancing made everyone laugh, but she kept trying with enthusiasm.

coffee.definition: A brewed drink prepared from roasted coffee beans.
examples: I love starting my day with a cup of coffee.
She asked for a coffee with milk and sugar.

cold stare.definition: A look that conveys indifference, disdain, or a lack of warmth, often used to express disapproval or detachment.
examples: She gave him a cold stare when he tried to joke about the serious situation.
The politician's cold stare at the press conference made everyone feel uneasy.

comes in.definition: 1. To arrive or appear at a place. 2. To be available in a particular form, size, or color. 3. (idiom) To be useful or convenient (comes in handy).
examples: The new phone comes in black, white, and blue.
The meeting comes in at 3 p.m.

commands.definition: A command is an instruction or directive given to someone or something to perform a specific action.
examples: The teacher gave the students commands to follow during the drill.
In the video game, players issue commands to control their units.

cooking.definition: The activity of preparing food by combining, mixing, and heating ingredients.
examples: She spent the afternoon cooking a hearty stew for her family.
The chef demonstrated how to cook the perfect steak at the culinary workshop.

counting.definition: The action or process of determining the number of something, or the act of enumerating items.
examples: I am counting the number of apples in the basket.
She was counting her money before making a purchase.

countries.definition: Plural of country; a nation or territory with its own government, borders, and population.
examples: Many countries have adopted renewable energy policies to combat climate change.
The conference will bring together representatives from several countries to discuss trade agreements.
expressions: countries with a high standard of living

currently.definition: at the present time; at the moment; now
examples: I am currently working on a new project.
The store is currently closed for renovations.

downstairs.definition: Located below or on a lower floor of a building; also used to refer to the lower part of a house or apartment.
examples: I left my keys downstairs, so I had to go back to get them.
The kitchen is downstairs, while the bedrooms are upstairs.

each other.definition: used to indicate that two or more people or things do something to each other
examples: They looked at each other.
The two teams congratulated each other after the game.

eachother.definition: used to refer to a reciprocal action or relationship between two or more people or things
examples: They helped each other finish the project on time.
The siblings always argue with each other, but they also support each other.

education.definition: The process of acquiring knowledge, skills, values, and habits through study, instruction, or experience, typically in a structured setting such as schools or universities.
examples: Education is the foundation for personal and societal growth.
She believes that education should be accessible to everyone.

enough.definition: Adequate in quantity or quality; sufficient to meet a need or requirement.
examples: I have enough money to buy a new laptop.
She didn't have enough time to finish the project.

everywhere.definition: In or to all places; at all places.
examples: She searched everywhere for her keys.
The news spread everywhere across the country.

firm.definition: A business organization that sells goods or services; a company.
examples: The firm announced a new product line at the conference.
She works for a small firm in downtown that specializes in graphic design.

fluency.definition: The ability to speak, write, or read a language smoothly, accurately, and with ease.
examples: Her fluency in Spanish impressed everyone at the conference.
The program focuses on improving students' reading fluency through repeated practice.

food.definition: Any substance that can be eaten or drunk by living organisms to provide energy and nutrients.
examples: She packed a sandwich and a bottle of water for lunch.
The restaurant offers a variety of international dishes.

food words.definition: Words related to food, such as names of foods, cooking terms, and expressions used in culinary contexts.
examples: I learned many food words in my culinary class.
The recipe book contains a list of food words to help beginners.

foot.definition: The lower extremity of the leg, used for standing, walking, or running; also a unit of length equal to 12 inches (30.48 cm).
examples: She planted her foot firmly on the ground before leaping.
The bridge is 100 feet long.
expressions: have a foot in both camps

for beauty.definition: Used to indicate that an action or decision is motivated by aesthetic considerations or the desire to achieve beauty.
examples: She trimmed the hedge for beauty.
They painted the walls for beauty.

for food.definition: A prepositional phrase indicating purpose or reason related to food, often used to describe a location, container, or activity intended for eating or storing food.
examples: We set up a table for food at the picnic.
She brought a bag for food to the camping trip.

for health.definition: Used to indicate a purpose or reason related to health or well-being.
examples: He exercises for health to maintain a strong heart.
She took the supplement for health to boost her immune system.

for her.definition: A prepositional phrase indicating purpose, benefit, or direction toward a female person.
examples: I bought this gift for her.
She was praised for her hard work.

for him.definition: A prepositional phrase indicating that something is intended for or benefits a male person.
examples: I bought a gift for him.
She cooked dinner for him.

for when.definition: A phrase used to refer to a future event or situation that may happen, often implying preparation or readiness; similar to 'in case' or 'when'.
examples: Bring an umbrella for when it rains.
I’ll keep the spare key for when you need it.
expressions: for when the lights go out

for women.definition: Used to indicate that something is intended or suitable for women.
examples: This dress is for women.
The workshop is for women only.

for work.definition: Used to indicate that something is done or intended for the purpose of employment or job duties.
examples: I need to finish this report for work before the deadline.
She is going to the office for work, so she will be late for the meeting.

gathers.definition: To bring together or collect; to assemble; to accumulate over time.
examples: She gathers the data from each experiment before analyzing the results.
The community gathers at the town hall every Friday to discuss local issues.

go to the.definition: A phrase indicating movement toward a specific place or destination.
examples: I go to the store every Saturday.
She goes to the doctor for a check‑up.

going to.definition: Used to express a planned action or future event, often with 'to' followed by a verb.
examples: I am going to study tonight.
She is going to visit her parents next week.

hand.definition: The prehensile, flexible part of the human arm that includes the fingers and thumb, used for grasping and manipulating objects.
examples: She held the cup with her hand.
He offered to lend a hand with the moving boxes.

handouts.definition: Printed materials distributed to people, often during a lecture, seminar, or meeting, to provide information, support, or instructions.
examples: The professor distributed handouts to the students before the lecture.
During the workshop, participants received handouts with step-by-step instructions.

head.definition: The upper part of the human body, containing the brain, eyes, ears, nose, and mouth; or the front or leading part of something.
examples: She wore a bright red hat on her head.
He took a head start on the race by arriving early.

headache.definition: A continuous pain in the head, often caused by tension, stress, or illness.
examples: I have a headache after staying up all night studying.
She took a painkiller to relieve her headache before the meeting.
expressions: headache in the back of my head

headaches.definition: pain or discomfort in the head or upper part of the body, often caused by stress, illness, or lack of sleep.
examples: I have a headache after staying up all night.
She suffered from frequent headaches during the exam period.

health.definition: The state of being free from illness or injury; overall physical and mental well-being.
examples: Regular exercise and a balanced diet are essential for maintaining good health.
The pandemic highlighted the importance of public health measures.
The horror movie featured a hideous monster that terrified the audience.
She found the idea of eating the spoiled food hideous and refused to try it.

home items.definition: Things or objects that are found in or used within a home, such as furniture, appliances, and decorative items.
examples: I need to buy new home items for the apartment, like a sofa and a lamp.
The cleaning crew will replace all the old home items with modern ones.

i think so.definition: A phrase used to express agreement or belief that something is true or will happen.
examples: "Will the train arrive on time?" "I think so."
"Do you think we should go to the party?" "I think so."

in a while.definition: After a short period of time; soon; within a brief time frame.
examples: I'll be back in a while.
You can finish the report in a while if you focus.
expressions: in a while, I'll be there
in a while, the traffic will clear
in a while, we will finish the project

influencer.definition: A person who has the power to influence the opinions or actions of others, especially through social media.
examples: She became a popular influencer by sharing her travel adventures on Instagram.
Brands often collaborate with influencers to promote their products to a wider audience.

inner city.definition: A part of a city that is located in the central area, often associated with lower-income neighborhoods and higher crime rates.
examples: Many inner-city schools struggle with limited resources and overcrowded classrooms.
The new community center aims to provide safe spaces for inner-city youth.

instead.definition: Used to indicate an alternative or substitution, meaning 'as an alternative to something else'.
examples: I will go to the park instead of staying home.
She chose tea instead of coffee.

investors.definition: Individuals or entities that allocate capital into projects, businesses, or ventures with the expectation of receiving financial returns or other benefits.
examples: The investors in the startup were thrilled by the rapid growth and early profitability.
Many investors prefer diversified portfolios to mitigate risk and ensure steady returns.

is thirsty.definition: Feeling the need for water or a desire for something, often used figuratively to express a strong desire or craving.
examples: After the long run, he is thirsty and needs a glass of water.
She is thirsty for knowledge and spends hours reading.

it is.definition: A contraction of 'it is', used to state a fact, describe a situation, or introduce a subject. It functions as a linking verb in present tense.
examples: It is raining outside.
It is a good idea to bring an umbrella.
expressions: It is not what you think

it led.definition: Past tense of 'lead', indicating that something caused or resulted in something else.
examples: It led to a major breakthrough in cancer research.
It led the team to victory after a long season.
expressions: It led to a new direction

itch.definition: A feeling that makes you want to scratch, or a strong desire to do something.
examples: I have an itch on my arm that I can't ignore.
He had an itch to travel the world.

its worth.definition: A phrase used to describe the value, importance, or usefulness of something.
examples: The antique vase is worth a lot of money, but its worth goes beyond its monetary value.
When deciding whether to invest, you should consider the project's worth.

knew.definition: Past tense of 'know', meaning to have knowledge or awareness of something.
examples: I knew the answer before the quiz started.
She knew the streets of the city like the back of her hand.
expressions: knew it was going to happen

learning.definition: The acquisition of knowledge, skills, or habits through study, experience, or instruction.
examples: She is dedicated to learning new languages.
Learning from mistakes is essential for growth.

math.definition: The abstract science of number, quantity, and space, especially as applied to solving problems.
examples: She studied math for three hours before the exam.
The math teacher explained the concept of fractions using real-life examples.

meaning.definition: The idea or concept that a word, phrase, or symbol represents.
examples: The meaning of the word "love" is complex and varies across cultures.
She couldn't find the meaning of his silence during the meeting.

might.definition: Used to express possibility, permission, or a suggestion in the past or present.
examples: It might rain later, so bring an umbrella.
She might have left early because she was feeling unwell.

my purpose.definition: The reason for which something is done or created, or for which something exists; a person's intended aim or goal.
examples: My purpose in studying English is to communicate with people from around the world.
When she asked why she was there, she replied, "My purpose is to help those in need."

necessity.definition: A thing that is needed or essential; a requirement or indispensable condition.
examples: Water is a necessity for all living organisms.
The necessity of a good education cannot be overstated.

nowhere.definition: Not in any place; no place; not found anywhere.
examples: I looked for my keys everywhere, but they were nowhere.
She felt like she was nowhere in the world.

often.definition: occurring or done many times, frequently
examples: She often goes to the gym after work.
I often forget my keys at home.

over there.definition: At a place that is not near the speaker, but within sight or reachable distance.
examples: I can see the house over there.
She pointed over there to indicate the direction.
expressions: over there, I can see the mountain
over there, we can find the restaurant
over there, the kids are playing
over there, the shop is closed

ownership.definition: The state or fact of owning something; the condition of being the owner of a particular thing or property.
examples: She claimed ownership of the antique vase after the auction.
The company’s ownership structure was complex, with many stakeholders.

people.definition: A group of human beings; individuals collectively.
examples: People gather in the park every Sunday to enjoy the music.
The people in this town are known for their hospitality.

plate.definition: A flat dish, typically made of ceramic, metal, or glass, used for serving or holding food.
examples: She placed the steaming soup on a silver plate before serving it to the guests.
The chef carefully plated the dish, arranging the garnish to make it look as appealing as it tasted.

reaches.definition: To arrive at a particular place or condition; to extend to; to achieve a goal or limit.
examples: She reaches the top of the mountain after a long hike.
The company's profits have reached a record high this quarter.

reading.definition: The action or skill of interpreting written or printed matter.
examples: She spent the afternoon reading a novel.
Reading improves vocabulary and comprehension.

reason.definition: A cause, explanation, or justification for an action or event.
examples: She gave a valid reason for her absence.
The reason for the delay was a technical malfunction.

relatives.definition: Family members related by blood or marriage
examples: I have many relatives who live in different countries.
During the holidays, we gather with our relatives for a big dinner.

right.definition: A moral or legal entitlement to have or do something; also a direction opposite of left; can mean correct or appropriate.
examples: She has the right to a fair trial.
Make sure you take the right turn at the intersection.

role play.definition: An activity in which participants act out or simulate a particular role or scenario, often used in training, therapy, or entertainment.
examples: During the workshop, the participants engaged in role play to practice customer service skills.
The therapist used role play to help the patient confront social anxiety.

seat.definition: A place or object where a person can sit; a position or role; the act of sitting in a seat.
examples: Please take a seat in the front row.
The seat of the chair was broken and needed repair.

security.definition: The state of being free from danger, threat, or risk; protection against harm.
examples: The security of the building was enhanced with new cameras.
She was worried about her financial security after losing her job.

she stands.definition: The phrase 'she stands' is the third-person singular present tense of the verb 'stand', meaning that she is in an upright position or that she remains in a particular state or position.
examples: She stands at the window, watching the rain fall.
She stands for equality and will not back down.

shiny word.definition: A word that is particularly appealing, attractive, or eye-catching, often used to describe marketing terms or buzzwords that sound impressive but may lack depth.
examples: The CEO used the shiny word "synergy" to impress the investors during the presentation.
In the article, the author highlighted the shiny word "innovation" as a key theme for the company's future.

ship word.definition: A noun that denotes a vessel used for traveling on water.
examples: The ship word "vessel" is often used in legal documents.
In everyday speech, people might use "boat" as a ship word.

shorter.definition: Comparative form of 'short', meaning having less length or duration than something else.
examples: She is shorter than her brother.
The shorter route takes less time.

shortest.definition: The one that has the least length or duration among a group or set.
examples: The shortest route to the museum is via the main street.
She completed the marathon in the shortest time of her career.

should.definition: Used to express obligation, duty, or recommendation, often in a polite or indirect way.
examples: You should study for the exam.
I should call my mother.

shout.definition: To speak or shout loudly, often to express strong emotion or to be heard over a distance.
examples: He shouted for help when the alarm went off.
She shouted at the top of her lungs during the concert.

show me.definition: A phrase used to request someone to demonstrate, reveal, or provide evidence of something, often implying a desire to see or understand it directly.
examples: Can you show me how to solve this equation?
Show me the documents you mentioned in the meeting.

slightly.definition: To a small degree; somewhat; not greatly, but a little.
examples: The soup was slightly salty, so I added more water.
She was slightly disappointed when the concert was canceled.

somewhere.definition: at or to a place that is not specified or known; at a particular location that is not identified
examples: I left my keys somewhere in the kitchen.
She disappeared somewhere in the city.

spanish.definition: Spanish is an adjective referring to Spain, its people, culture, or language, and also a noun denoting the Romance language spoken in Spain and many Latin American countries.
examples: She studied Spanish at university to prepare for her trip to Madrid.
The Spanish cuisine features tapas, paella, and a variety of olive oils.

steadfast.definition: Firmly fixed or unwavering in purpose, loyalty, or determination.
examples: She remained steadfast in her commitment to the cause.
His steadfast determination helped him overcome the obstacles.

sunshine.definition: The light and warmth that comes from the sun.
examples: After the storm, the sunshine made the garden look vibrant.
She smiled as the sunshine filtered through the curtains.

surgery.definition: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis and treatment of injuries and diseases by manual and instrumental techniques, especially operations.
examples: She underwent surgery to repair the torn ligament.
The surgeon performed a complex surgery on the patient's heart.

tall short.definition: A phrase that juxtaposes two opposing qualities, often used humorously to describe something that is both tall and short at the same time, or to refer to a short story that is a tall tale.
examples: The comedian told a tall short about a giant who could fit in a shoebox.
Her explanation was a tall short: a brief but exaggerated tale of her trip to Mars.

teacher.definition: A person who teaches, especially in a school or university.
examples: The teacher explained the lesson clearly.
She became a teacher after completing her degree.

tema often.definition: A combination of the noun 'tema' (theme) and the adverb 'often', indicating that a theme is used or appears frequently.
examples: In many novels, the theme of redemption often appears.
The teacher often uses the theme of cooperation in his lessons.

tema there.definition: A subject or topic of discussion, especially in literature or art.
examples: The tema there was the conflict between tradition and modernity.
In the conference, the tema there was climate change.

tema those.definition: A phrase used to refer to multiple themes that are being pointed out or discussed.
examples: I found the book's discussion on those themes to be insightful.
She highlighted those themes in her presentation.

tema whose.definition: A phrase that combines the noun 'tema' (meaning 'theme' or 'subject') with the relative pronoun 'whose', used to indicate possession or association.
examples: The tema whose colors are vibrant attracts attention.
She studied the tema whose origins trace back to ancient folklore.

temporary.definition: lasting for only a limited period of time; not permanent.
examples: The company hired a temporary worker to cover the vacation of a permanent employee.
She was given a temporary visa to stay in the country while her application was processed.

that.definition: That is a demonstrative pronoun, determiner, adjective, or conjunction used to refer to a specific thing or to introduce a clause.
examples: I think that you are right.
That book is mine.

that itch.definition: A phrase used to describe a strong urge or desire to do something, often implying that the person feels compelled to act on it.
examples: I have that itch to travel and see new places.
She couldn't ignore that itch to start her own business.

that was.definition: Used to refer to something that has already happened or to describe a past situation.
examples: That was the best concert I've ever attended.
When I saw the accident, I thought, "That was a close call."

that word.definition: A specific word that has been mentioned or is understood from context.
examples: I don't like that word.
She said that word and everyone laughed.
expressions: that word is a curse word
that word is a technical term
that word is a slang term
that word is a taboo word

thats fine.definition: An informal expression used to indicate that a situation or proposal is acceptable or satisfactory.
examples: A: Can I borrow your car tonight? B: That's fine, just be careful.
She apologized for being late, and I said, 'That's fine.'

the store.definition: A place where goods or services are sold to customers, typically a retail establishment.
examples: I need to go to the store to buy milk.
The store was closed on Sundays.

the wind.definition: The natural movement of air, especially when it is strong or moving in a particular direction.
examples: The wind was so strong that it knocked over the trees.
She listened to the wind as it whispered through the leaves.

them.definition: "them" is a third-person plural object pronoun used to refer to people or things previously mentioned.
examples: I saw them at the park.
She gave the books to them.

there.definition: Adverb or pronoun used to indicate a place or existence; also used in expressions such as 'there is', 'there are', 'therefore', etc.
examples: She put the book over there on the shelf.
There are five people waiting in line.

there are.definition: A phrase used to indicate the existence or presence of multiple items or people in a particular place or situation.
examples: There are five books on the table.
There are no more tickets left for the concert.

there is.definition: Used to indicate the existence of something.
examples: There is a book on the table.
There is no way to finish it.

there isnt.definition: Used to indicate that something does not exist or is not present.
examples: There isn't any milk left in the fridge.
There isn't a single reason why we should wait.

they are.definition: Contraction of 'they' and 'are', used as a subject-verb phrase in the present tense to describe or state something about a group of people or things.
examples: They are studying for their exams.
They are not ready for the trip yet.

they arent.definition: Contraction of 'they are not', used to negate the verb 'to be' for the third-person plural.
examples: They aren't going to the party tonight.
They aren't ready for the exam yet.
expressions: They aren't going to be late
They aren't sure about the plan

thing.definition: An object, item, or concept that can be identified or described.
examples: I found a strange thing in the attic.
He said he had a thing to do.

think.definition: To use one's mind to consider, reason, or form an opinion about something.
examples: I think the movie was better than I expected.
She thinks about her future plans every night.

think in.definition: to consider something using a particular perspective or framework, often implying a specific way of processing information
examples: She tends to think in colors rather than numbers when she designs her artwork.
When planning the project, we must think in terms of budget constraints and realistic timelines.

think verb.definition: To use one's mind to consider, reason, or form an opinion about something; to have an idea or belief.
examples: I think the meeting will start at 3 PM.
She thinks that the new policy will improve efficiency.

this that.definition: A colloquial phrase meaning various things or a mix of items, often used when the speaker is vague or refers to many items without specifying them.
examples: I bought this that from the market, but I don't remember exactly what it was.
She kept this that on the shelf, a mix of old letters and photographs.

thoroughly.definition: in a complete and careful way; with great attention to detail.
examples: She thoroughly cleaned the house before the guests arrived.
He thoroughly enjoyed the concert, praising every performance.

those.definition: Plural demonstrative pronoun used to refer to something far from the speaker.
examples: Those books on the shelf belong to my sister.
I remember those days when we used to play outside.
expressions: those are the ones I like

to belong.definition: To be the property of; to be a member of; to have a connection to something or someone.
examples: The house belongs to me.
She belongs to the choir.

to bloom.definition: To produce flowers or to develop and become fully grown; to prosper or flourish.
examples: The roses will bloom in late spring.
After years of hard work, her career finally bloomed.

to borrow.definition: To take and use something owned by someone else for a temporary period, with the intention of returning it.
examples: I will borrow a book from the library for the weekend.
Can I borrow your pen while you finish this task?

to have.definition: To possess, own, or hold something.
examples: I have a new car.
She has been working here for five years.

advanced english.definition: Advanced English refers to a high level of proficiency in the English language, encompassing complex grammar, nuanced vocabulary, and the ability to understand and produce sophisticated written and spoken communication.

engaged explained.definition: "Engaged explained" is not a standard idiom; it can be understood as either (1) explaining something in an engaging way, or (2) being engaged while explaining. It generally refers to the act of explaining with enthusiasm, involvement, and clarity.
examples: The presenter engaged the audience by explaining the complex theory in simple terms.
During the workshop, the facilitator engaged the participants by explaining the steps clearly and interactively.
expressions: to explain in an engaging way

english adjectives.definition: Adjectives are words that describe or modify nouns, indicating qualities, quantities, or states. In English, adjectives typically precede the noun they modify or follow linking verbs.
examples: The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
She wore a bright red dress to the party.

english advanced.definition: A level of proficiency in English that goes beyond intermediate, characterized by a deep understanding of complex grammar, a broad vocabulary, and the ability to use the language fluently and accurately in both written and spoken contexts.
examples: She enrolled in an advanced English course to prepare for her upcoming TOEFL exam.
The advanced English curriculum includes literature analysis, advanced writing techniques, and critical thinking exercises.

english adverb.definition: An adverb is a word that modifies a verb, adjective, or another adverb, indicating manner, place, time, frequency, degree, or other circumstances of the action or state.
examples: She sings beautifully.
He runs quickly.
expressions: at the end of the day

english adverbs.definition: Adverbs are words that modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs, indicating manner, place, time, frequency, degree, or purpose.
examples: She sings beautifully.
They will arrive soon.

english alternative.definition: A phrase used to describe an alternative version or choice that is expressed in English, often referring to a different wording, synonym, or translation of a term.
examples: Instead of saying 'happy', you could use the English alternative 'joyful'.
The English alternative for the Spanish word 'casa' is 'house'.

english apostrophe.definition: An apostrophe (') in English is a punctuation mark used primarily to indicate possession (e.g., "John's book") or to show omitted letters in contractions (e.g., "don't", "it's").
examples: Don't forget to bring your book.
It's John's book.

english basics.definition: The essential elements of English language learning, including basic grammar, vocabulary, pronunciation, and everyday communication skills.
examples: Learning English basics helps you form simple sentences.
Before tackling advanced literature, you should master the English basics.

english business.definition: Business activities conducted in the English language, often referring to international trade, services, or corporate environments where English is the primary medium of communication.
examples: The multinational firm requires all its internal reports to be written in English business to ensure consistency across its global offices.
She specializes in English business, helping startups translate their marketing materials and negotiate contracts with overseas partners.

english channel.definition: A television or radio channel that broadcasts content in the English language, often used for language learning or entertainment.
examples: I watch the English channel every evening to practice my listening skills.
The English channel offers a variety of programs for learners of all levels.

english class.definition: A class or session where students learn the English language, covering topics such as grammar, vocabulary, reading, writing, listening, and speaking.
examples: I have an English class at 10 a.m. every Monday and Wednesday.
During English class, we practiced pronunciation by reading short stories aloud.

english clickbait.definition: A type of sensationalized headline or content designed to attract clicks, often by exaggerating or misleading the reader.
examples: \"You won't believe what happened next!\" is a classic example of English clickbait used to entice readers.
The article titled \"10 Secrets to Instant Wealth\" is typical English clickbait that promises quick results.

english comparisons.definition: English comparisons refer to the use of comparative and superlative forms of adjectives and adverbs to express differences in degree between two or more items.
examples: She is taller than her brother.
This exam is harder than the last one.

english conjunctions.definition: Conjunctions are words that connect clauses, sentences, or words within a sentence. They help show relationships such as addition, contrast, cause, condition, or time.
examples: I wanted to go to the park, but it started raining.
She can either stay home or go to the party.

english content.definition: Content that is written, spoken, or presented in the English language, often used in media, education, or marketing to reach English-speaking audiences.
examples: The website offers a mix of Spanish and English content to cater to both local and international visitors.
She specializes in creating engaging English content for online learning platforms.

english conversation.definition: A spoken interaction between two or more people in the English language, often used to practice language skills or discuss topics.
examples: During the workshop, participants engaged in an English conversation to improve their fluency.
The teacher encouraged students to start an English conversation with a partner about their weekend plans.

english cooking.definition: The style of cooking associated with England, featuring dishes such as roast beef, fish and chips, shepherd's pie, and traditional puddings, often characterized by hearty, comforting flavors and simple, rustic techniques.
examples: I love the hearty flavors of English cooking, especially the Sunday roast with all the trimmings.
The new bistro specializes in English cooking, offering classic pies, crumpets, and sticky toffee pudding.

english daily usage.definition: The everyday, practical use of the English language in daily life, encompassing common phrases, idioms, and conversational patterns.
examples: I practice my English daily usage by chatting with friends online and reading news articles.
Her English daily usage improved significantly after she started watching English movies with subtitles.

english difference.definition: The phrase 'English difference' refers to the distinctions or variations found within the English language, such as differences in grammar, vocabulary, pronunciation, or usage between dialects or between English and other languages.
examples: The English difference between British and American spelling can be confusing for learners.
Understanding the English difference in verb tenses is crucial for accurate communication.
expressions: English difference between X and Y

english education.definition: The study and teaching of the English language, encompassing its grammar, vocabulary, literature, and usage skills.
examples: She pursued an English education at university, focusing on linguistics and literature.
The school offers a comprehensive English education program that includes reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills.

english examples.definition: Instances or samples of English language usage, often used to illustrate grammar, vocabulary, or usage.
examples: The teacher asked the students to write a paragraph using past tense, providing English examples of verb conjugation.
She used the word 'serendipity' in her essay, offering an English example of a rare vocabulary term.

english expression.definition: A phrase or set of words used in English to convey a particular meaning or sentiment, often idiomatic or culturally specific.
examples: "It's raining cats and dogs." – meaning it is raining very heavily.
"Break a leg." – a way to wish someone good luck, especially before a performance.
expressions: hit the nail on the head
let the cat out of the bag

english expressions.definition: A set of phrases or idioms used in the English language to convey particular meanings or emotions.
examples: She used the expression "break the ice" to start the conversation.
He said "hit the books" when he needed to study.

english family terms.definition: A set of words used to describe members of a family and their relationships, such as mother, father, sister, brother, aunt, uncle, cousin, etc.
examples: My sister is studying medicine at the university.
We visited our grandparents last weekend.

english family words.definition: A set of English words that refer to family members, relationships, or family-related concepts, such as 'mother', 'brother', 'cousin', 'kin', 'relatives', 'ancestry', and 'household'.
examples: My sister and I share a strong bond; we consider each other family.
The genealogist traced the family tree back to the 17th century.

english fluency.definition: The ability to speak, read, write, and understand English with ease and accuracy, often implying a high level of proficiency and naturalness in communication.
examples: After years of study, Maria achieved English fluency, allowing her to work comfortably in multinational teams.
The course is designed to help students reach English fluency by focusing on real-life conversation and advanced grammar.

english food.definition: The traditional cuisine of England, known for dishes such as fish and chips, roast beef with Yorkshire pudding, shepherd's pie, and a variety of hearty stews and pies. It often features simple, comforting ingredients and reflects the country’s agricultural heritage.
examples: After a long day of hiking, we enjoyed a hearty bowl of English stew at the local pub.
She surprised her guests with a classic English roast dinner, complete with roast potatoes and Yorkshire pudding.

english for adults.definition: A program or course that teaches the English language specifically designed for adult learners, often focusing on practical communication skills, workplace vocabulary, and cultural context.
examples: She enrolled in an English for adults class to improve her conversational skills before the business trip.
The community center offers free English for adults sessions every Saturday morning.

english for advanced.definition: A level of English proficiency that goes beyond basic communication, encompassing advanced grammar, vocabulary, idiomatic expressions, and the ability to discuss complex topics, analyze texts, and produce sophisticated written and spoken content.
examples: After completing the intermediate course, she enrolled in an English for Advanced program to refine her academic writing skills.
The university offers an English for Advanced workshop that focuses on critical reading and advanced discourse analysis.

english for banking.definition: A specialized form of English used in the banking sector, covering terminology, communication skills, and procedures related to financial services such as loans, deposits, investments, and regulatory compliance.
examples: During the training, the participants learned how to draft a loan agreement in clear, professional English.
The customer service representative used banking English to explain the new online banking features to the client.

english for beauty.definition: The use of the English language in contexts related to beauty, such as beauty blogs, product descriptions, tutorials, and industry communication.
examples: The beauty influencer shared her "English for beauty" tips on how to apply makeup using simple, clear language.
In the course, students learned "English for beauty" to write engaging product reviews and marketing copy.
expressions: beauty is in the eye of the beholder
beauty is a state of mind

english for business.definition: A specialized form of English used in business contexts, covering topics such as negotiations, presentations, reports, and corporate communication.
examples: She enrolled in an English for Business course to improve her email etiquette and negotiation skills.
During the conference, the speaker used English for Business terminology to explain the quarterly financial results.
expressions: to run it up the chain

english for career.definition: A specialized form of English language learning focused on the skills, vocabulary, and communication strategies needed for professional success in a specific industry or workplace. It includes business writing, presentations, negotiations, networking, and industry-specific terminology.
examples: After completing the English for Career program, Maria was able to confidently give her first presentation to senior executives in her company.
The university offers an English for Career course that covers resume writing, interview techniques, and cross-cultural communication for international business.

english for coffee.definition: The specific English vocabulary and expressions used in coffee shop settings, such as ordering drinks, asking for recommendations, and engaging in casual conversation with baristas.
examples: Before visiting Italy, I practiced English for coffee so I could confidently order a cappuccino at any café.
During her internship, she learned English for coffee by chatting with the baristas and asking about the daily specials.

english for cooking.definition: English for cooking refers to the specific vocabulary, phrases, and expressions used in culinary contexts, such as recipes, cooking techniques, and kitchen operations.
examples: I enrolled in an English for cooking course to improve my ability to read international recipes.
The chef taught us English for cooking terms like "julienne", "simmer", and "sauté".

english for doctors.definition: English language specialized for medical professionals, covering terminology, patient communication, and clinical documentation.
examples: The doctor used medical English to explain the diagnosis to the patient.
She enrolled in an English for doctors course to improve her patient interactions.

english for emails.definition: The specific style, tone, and vocabulary used when writing emails in English, including greetings, closings, and concise, polite phrasing suitable for professional and informal electronic communication.
examples: I have attached the report you requested; please let me know if you need any further information.
Thank you for your prompt response. I look forward to our meeting next week.
expressions: I hope this message finds you well.
Please let me know if you have any questions.
Looking forward to hearing from you.

english for emotions.definition: A specialized use of English focused on expressing, describing, and discussing emotions, often employed in therapy, counseling, or emotional literacy contexts.
examples: During the counseling session, she used English for emotions to articulate her feelings after the breakup.
In the workshop, participants practiced English for emotions to better communicate their inner experiences to others.

english for esl.definition: English for ESL refers to teaching English language skills to non‑native speakers who are learning English as a second language.
examples: The university offers an English for ESL program that focuses on academic writing and listening comprehension.
She enrolled in an English for ESL course to improve her conversational skills and prepare for a job abroad.

english for everyday.definition: English used in daily life, covering basic conversational topics, common phrases, and everyday situations.
examples: I need to learn English for everyday communication at work and in social settings.
She uses English for everyday tasks like ordering coffee, asking for directions, and chatting with friends.

english for finance.definition: English language specialized for finance, covering terminology, communication skills, and concepts used in banking, investment, accounting, and corporate finance.
examples: She enrolled in an English for Finance course to improve her ability to read quarterly reports and discuss market trends with international clients.
The new analyst needed English for Finance training to accurately translate the audit findings into clear, concise reports for the board.

english for food.definition: The use of English language in the context of food, including vocabulary, expressions, and communication related to cooking, dining, and food service.
examples: When ordering at a restaurant, it's helpful to know common English phrases like 'Could I have the menu, please?'
In a cooking class, the instructor explains the steps in English, using terms like 'preheat', 'sauté', and 'bake'.
expressions: Could I have a glass of water?
Do you have any vegetarian options?
Can I get the bill, please?

english for health.definition: English language used in health-related contexts, including medical terminology, patient communication, and healthcare settings.
examples: The course focuses on medical terminology and how to explain diagnoses to patients in clear English.
During the internship, she practiced patient communication in English, ensuring accurate and empathetic exchanges.

english for hobbies.definition: Learning or using English language skills specifically tailored to discuss, describe, and enjoy various hobbies and leisure activities.
examples: I joined an online forum where we practice English for hobbies, sharing tips on gardening and photography.
She enrolled in a course that focuses on English for hobbies, helping her talk about her new interest in woodworking.

english for home.definition: The use of the English language within a domestic setting, such as communicating with family members, managing household tasks, or learning English for personal use at home.
examples: She enrolled in an online course to improve her English for home, so she could help her children with their homework.
The family uses English for home to maintain a shared language while traveling abroad.

english for injuries.definition: The use of the English language to describe, assess, and manage injuries in a medical context.
examples: During the emergency briefing, the paramedic used English for injuries to explain the severity of the patient's wounds.
The medical report was written in English for injuries, detailing the fracture and recommended treatment plan.

english for jobs.definition: English language skills tailored to professional contexts, focusing on vocabulary, communication, and writing relevant to specific job sectors.
examples: She enrolled in an English for jobs course to improve her resume and interview skills.
The company offers an English for jobs program that covers business communication and industry-specific terminology.

english for learners.definition: A form of English instruction designed specifically for non-native speakers, focusing on practical language skills, grammar, vocabulary, and cultural context to help learners communicate effectively in everyday situations.
examples: The university offers an English for Learners program that starts with basic conversation skills and gradually introduces academic writing.
Many online platforms provide English for Learners courses that include interactive quizzes, video lessons, and live tutoring sessions.

english for medicine.definition: The study and use of English language skills tailored specifically for medical professionals, including terminology, patient communication, clinical documentation, and understanding of medical literature.
examples: After completing the course, she felt confident using English for medicine during her clinical rotations abroad.
The conference offered a workshop on English for medicine, focusing on accurate prescription writing and patient interviews.

english for nature.definition: A specialized use of the English language focused on describing, studying, and communicating about natural environments, wildlife, and ecological concepts.
examples: The guide used English for nature to explain the migration patterns of birds during the field trip.
In the field manual, English for nature terminology helps scientists discuss conservation strategies with clarity.

english for reading.definition: A specialized form of English language instruction focused on developing reading skills, comprehension, and fluency in academic and literary texts.
examples: The course on English for reading helps students analyze complex literary passages.
English for reading programs often include strategies for skimming, scanning, and critical analysis.

english for school.definition: English language instruction designed specifically for use in school settings, emphasizing academic vocabulary, reading comprehension, and writing skills.
examples: She enrolled in an English for school program to improve her grades.
The teacher assigned a project in English for school to prepare students for exams.

english for shopping.definition: English language skills and vocabulary used when shopping, including asking for prices, sizes, and assistance, as well as making purchases and handling returns.
examples: Could you tell me how much this shirt costs?
I would like to return this item; it doesn't fit.
expressions: Do you have this in a different color?

english for speaking.definition: English language used primarily for speaking, focusing on oral communication skills such as pronunciation, fluency, and conversational practice.
examples: I enrolled in an English for speaking course to improve my pronunciation and confidence in conversations.
During the workshop, we practiced common expressions and role‑plays to enhance our speaking abilities.

english for students.definition: A specialized English language program or course designed to meet the needs of students, often focusing on academic skills, exam preparation, and everyday communication.
examples: She enrolled in an English for students program to improve her academic writing and research skills.
The university offers English for students courses that focus on exam preparation and academic reading.

english for teachers.definition: A specialized English language program designed for teachers, focusing on pedagogical strategies, classroom management, and subject‑specific terminology to enhance their ability to teach English effectively.
examples: The university offers an intensive course in English for teachers, covering lesson planning and assessment techniques.
After completing the English for teachers program, Maria felt confident in leading her students through advanced grammar lessons.

english for tech.definition: A specialized form of English used in the technology sector, encompassing terminology, communication styles, and writing conventions relevant to software development, IT support, and digital innovation.
examples: She enrolled in an English for Tech course to improve her ability to read technical documentation.
The conference featured a workshop on English for Tech, focusing on how to write clear API documentation.

english for travel.definition: A set of English language skills and vocabulary focused on everyday situations encountered while traveling, such as booking accommodations, navigating transportation, ordering food, and asking for directions.
examples: When I arrived at the airport, I used my English for travel skills to ask the gate agent for the boarding gate number.
During the city tour, I practiced my English for travel phrases to order a local dish at the restaurant.
expressions: Where is the nearest bus stop?
Can I have a table for two, please?
How much does a ticket to the museum cost?
Could you recommend a good hotel in this area?
I need a taxi to the airport.
What time does the train depart?
Could you show me on the map?
I would like to check out, please.

english for weather.translation: expressões em inglês sobre o clima
english for weather.definition: Common English expressions and vocabulary used to describe weather conditions and talk about weather.
examples: It's raining cats and dogs.
The forecast says it'll be sunny all week.
expressions: The weather is a bit gloomy

english for women.definition: A specialized English language program or course designed specifically for women, focusing on topics relevant to women's interests, empowerment, and professional development.
examples: The university launched an English for Women program to help female students improve their communication skills for the global job market.
She enrolled in an English for Women workshop to learn business vocabulary and networking strategies tailored to female entrepreneurs.

english for work.definition: English language skills used in a professional or workplace context, including business communication, meetings, reports, emails, and negotiations.
examples: She enrolled in an English for Work course to improve her business email writing.
During the conference, he demonstrated his English for Work skills by presenting a detailed project report.

english for writing.definition: English for writing refers to the study and application of English language skills specifically aimed at producing written texts, including grammar, vocabulary, style, and structure.
examples: She enrolled in an English for writing course to improve her academic essays.
The workshop focuses on English for writing techniques used in business reports.

english future plans.definition: Future plans are the intentions or arrangements one makes for events that will happen later.
examples: I have future plans to study abroad next year.
She discussed her future plans with her career counselor.

english future tense.definition: The future tense in English expresses actions that will happen after the present moment. It is often formed with will/shall + base verb, or with be going to + base verb, or simple present for scheduled events.
examples: I will finish the report tomorrow.
She is going to travel to Japan next month.

english greetings.definition: Common phrases used to greet someone in English, often varying by time of day, formality, and context.
examples: Hello! How are you today?
Good morning, everyone. I hope you’re all doing well.

english handouts.definition: Printed or digital materials provided to students or participants that contain information, instructions, or resources in English, often used for teaching or reference.
examples: The teacher handed out the English handouts before the lesson began.
Students can download the English handouts from the course website.

english humor.definition: A style of humor that is characteristic of English-speaking cultures, often featuring irony, understatement, wordplay, and a dry or sarcastic tone.
examples: In a classic British sitcom, the characters often use witty banter and subtle sarcasm to create humor.
The comedian’s jokes rely on clever puns and a dry delivery that is typical of English humor.
expressions: to have a British sense of humor
to make a joke in a subtle way

english idiom.definition: A phrase or expression that has a figurative meaning different from the literal meaning of its individual words, commonly used in everyday speech.
examples: "Break the ice" means to initiate conversation or ease tension in a social setting.
"Spill the beans" means to reveal a secret or disclose information prematurely.
expressions: Let the cat out of the bag

english idioms.definition: An idiom is a phrase or expression whose meaning cannot be deduced from the literal meanings of its individual words. English idioms are commonly used expressions that convey figurative meanings.
examples: "It's raining cats and dogs."
"Break the ice."
expressions: hit the nail on the head
let the cat out of the bag
cost an arm and a leg
the ball is in your court

english influencer.definition: A person who uses social media platforms to influence others by sharing English language learning tips, cultural insights, or language-related content, often aiming to inspire or educate their audience.
examples: The English influencer posted a series of short videos explaining common idioms, which quickly went viral among language learners.
By collaborating with a popular English influencer, the brand was able to reach a younger, global audience interested in improving their language skills.

english intermediate.definition: A proficiency level in English where learners can understand and produce more complex sentences, use a broader vocabulary, and handle everyday communication with some confidence.
examples: She has an intermediate English level, so she can discuss her hobbies in detail.
The course is designed for students with intermediate English skills.
expressions: Can you explain that in more detail?
Could you give me an example?
I think I might have misunderstood.

english language.definition: The language spoken primarily in England, the United States, Canada, Australia, and many other countries; a West Germanic language.
examples: She studied the English language for her degree.
Learning the English language opens up many opportunities.

english learning.definition: The process or activity of acquiring knowledge, skills, and proficiency in the English language.
examples: She is learning English to improve her career prospects in international business.
They started learning English at a local community college, focusing on speaking and listening skills.

english legal terms.definition: English legal terms refer to the specialized vocabulary used in the legal profession, including words and phrases that have specific meanings in law, such as 'plaintiff', 'jurisdiction', 'indemnity', etc.
examples: The lawyer explained the English legal terms to the client to ensure they understood the contract.
During the trial, the judge asked the witness to clarify the English legal terms used in the deposition.

english lesson.definition: An English lesson is a structured session where learners study the English language, covering topics such as grammar, vocabulary, reading, writing, listening, and speaking skills.
examples: During the English lesson, the teacher introduced the past tense and gave us exercises to practice.
The online English lesson was recorded so we could review the pronunciation tips later.

english lesson 2.definition: The second instructional session in an English language course, typically focusing on foundational grammar concepts such as the present simple tense, basic sentence structure, and introductory vocabulary.
examples: During English lesson 2, the teacher introduced the present simple tense and had students practice forming affirmative sentences.
In English lesson 2, we reviewed the difference between 'a' and 'an' and practiced using them in context.

english lesson video.definition: A video that provides instruction, explanations, or practice exercises for learning English, often used in classroom or self-study settings.
examples: I watched an English lesson video on pronunciation before the exam.
The teacher assigned an English lesson video to help students review the grammar unit.

english lessons.definition: Structured sessions or courses designed to teach the English language, covering grammar, vocabulary, reading, writing, listening, and speaking skills.
examples: I enrolled in English lessons to improve my conversational skills before the trip.
The school offers free English lessons to all students after school hours.
expressions: English lessons at a language center

english listening.definition: The skill of understanding spoken language in English, often practiced through listening exercises, audio recordings, and real-life conversations.
examples: I improve my English listening by watching English movies without subtitles.
During the workshop, we practiced English listening by listening to a podcast and answering comprehension questions.

english market words.definition: English words commonly used in market contexts, such as terms related to buying, selling, pricing, stocks, investments, and economic analysis.
examples: The market is bullish today, so many investors are buying stocks.
She studied market trends to decide when to sell her shares.

english modal verbs.definition: Modal verbs are auxiliary verbs that express ability, possibility, necessity, permission, or obligation. They include can, could, may, might, shall, should, will, would, must, and others.
examples: She can speak three languages fluently.
You should finish your homework before watching TV.

english motivation.definition: The drive or desire that encourages a person to study and improve their English language skills, often fueled by personal goals, career opportunities, or a love of culture.
examples: She found her english motivation when she realized that mastering the language could open doors to international travel.
His english motivation grew after he started watching movies without subtitles and wanted to understand every word.

english nouns.definition: A noun is a part of speech that names a person, place, thing, or idea. In English, nouns can be singular or plural, common or proper, and can function as subjects, objects, or complements in a sentence.
examples: The cat slept on the mat.
She bought a new car.

english numbers.definition: The representation of numbers using English words and numerals, such as "twenty-three" or "1,000".
examples: Twenty-three (23)
One hundred and fifty (150)

english obligation.definition: A duty or responsibility that must be fulfilled, often expressed in the English language. In grammar, it refers to the use of modal verbs such as must, have to, should, etc., to indicate necessity or obligation.
examples: You have an English obligation to submit the report by Friday.
The contract includes an English obligation that the tenant must pay rent on time.

english participle.definition: A participle is a form of a verb that functions as an adjective or part of a verb phrase. In English, there are two main types: the present participle (ending in -ing) and the past participle (usually ending in -ed, -en, or irregular forms). Present participles are used in continuous tenses and as adjectives, while past participles are used in perfect tenses and as adjectives.
examples: She was **running** late for the meeting.
The **broken** window was repaired yesterday.

english past tense.definition: The English past tense is a verb form that indicates actions or states that occurred before the present time. It is used to describe completed events, habitual actions in the past, and past conditions.
examples: I walked to the store yesterday.
She had finished her homework before dinner.
expressions: I went to the party last night.
He had already left when I arrived.

english phrase.definition: A group of words that conveys a particular meaning or function in English, often used as a unit in speech or writing.
examples: She used a common English phrase like "break the ice" to start the conversation.
The teacher asked the students to write an essay using at least three English phrases.

english phrase ahead.definition: Adverb or adjective meaning in front, earlier, or superior in position or progress; also used to indicate being ahead of a schedule or expectation.
examples: She is ahead of the class in the race.
We are ahead of schedule and can finish early.

english phrase even.definition: Used to emphasize that something is true or happens despite expectations, or to highlight an extreme example.
examples: Even though it was raining, we went out.
Even John, who is usually shy, spoke up.

english phrase sure.definition: Used to express agreement, confirmation, or certainty, often in response to a question or statement.
examples: Are you going to the meeting? Sure, I'll be there.
Do you want to try the new dish? Sure, I'm up for it.

english phrase usage.definition: The practice of selecting and applying appropriate English phrases in communication to convey meaning effectively.
examples: When writing a formal email, proper English phrase usage can make the tone more professional.
In casual conversation, using idiomatic expressions demonstrates fluency and enhances rapport.
expressions: hit the nail on the head
the ball is in your court

english phrase video.definition: A video that teaches or demonstrates English phrases, often used for language learning and conversational practice.
examples: I watched an English phrase video to improve my conversational skills before the trip.
The teacher assigned an English phrase video for homework to help students learn everyday expressions.

english phrasebook.definition: A reference book containing common phrases and expressions in English, often used by travelers to aid communication.
examples: I bought an English phrasebook before my trip to London to help me order food.
The English phrasebook includes useful greetings, travel phrases, and emergency expressions.

english phrases.definition: A collection of words or a short sentence that conveys a particular meaning or idea in the English language. English phrases can be idiomatic, colloquial, or formal, and are often used to express common concepts, emotions, or actions.
examples: She said, "It's raining cats and dogs," meaning it was raining heavily.
He used the phrase "break the ice" to describe starting a conversation in a relaxed way.
expressions: hit the nail on the head
let the cat out of the bag
the ball is in your court
cost an arm and a leg

english portuguese.definition: A term used to describe the English language as it is spoken in Portugal, or a bilingual reference to both English and Portuguese languages.
examples: She is fluent in English Portuguese and can easily switch between the two languages during conversations.
The university offers an English Portuguese course that covers grammar, pronunciation, and cultural nuances of both languages.

english possessive.definition: The possessive form in English indicates ownership or a relationship, typically formed by adding an apostrophe and "s" to a noun or by using "of" for plural nouns.
examples: John's book is on the table.
The cat's whiskers are very long.

english practice.definition: The act of engaging in activities designed to improve one's proficiency in the English language, such as speaking, listening, reading, and writing exercises.
examples: She attends an English practice group every Saturday to improve her conversational skills.
The teacher assigned a series of English practice worksheets to reinforce grammar concepts.

english prepositions.definition: Prepositions are words that show the relationship between a noun (or pronoun) and other words in a sentence, indicating direction, location, time, or other abstract relationships.
examples: She walked **to** the park.
The book is **on** the table.

english pronouns.definition: Pronouns are words that replace nouns or noun phrases in a sentence, such as 'he', 'she', 'they', 'it', 'who', 'which', etc., to avoid repetition and clarify reference.
examples: She went to the store because she needed milk.
They are planning to travel next summer.

english reading.definition: The activity of reading texts written in the English language, often used to improve language skills, comprehension, and vocabulary.

hightech.definition: Relating to or using advanced technology, especially in the context of modern, sophisticated equipment or systems.
examples: The new smartphone features high-tech sensors that can detect subtle changes in the user's environment.
She works for a high-tech startup that develops AI-powered medical diagnostics.

hired.definition: Past tense of hire; employed or engaged by an employer for a job or task.
examples: She was hired as a project manager after the interview.
They hired a new engineer to lead the development team.

hold on.definition: 1. To wait for a short time. 2. To remain in place or hold something firmly.
examples: Hold on, I'll be right back.
Hold on to the railing while you cross the bridge.

hold safer security.definition: The phrase "hold safer security" is not a standard idiom in English. It can be interpreted as a suggestion to maintain or adopt a more secure approach or practice, often used in contexts such as information technology, physical safety, or risk management.
examples: To protect customer data, the company decided to hold safer security protocols in place, ensuring all systems were updated and monitored.
During the safety audit, the contractor was advised to hold safer security measures, including reinforced barriers and stricter access controls.

hottest country.definition: A phrase used to describe the country that experiences the highest average temperatures or the most extreme heat conditions, often referring to its climate or weather patterns.
examples: Many travelers avoid the hottest country during the summer months.
The hottest country in the world is often considered to be Kuwait, with temperatures exceeding 50°C.
expressions: the hottest country in the world

house items.definition: Things or objects that are found in or used within a house.
examples: I bought new house items like a sofa and a dining table for the living room.
The house items were organized in the storage closet after the renovation.

household items.definition: Objects or goods that are commonly found in a home and used for daily living, such as furniture, appliances, utensils, and other household necessities.
examples: I need to buy some household items for the new apartment, like a sofa, a refrigerator, and a set of dishes.
